title: Structural Engineer I
pros: The company offers generous PTO, a decent benefit package, the option to purchase stock, a wellness reimbursement, and the occasional team/company field trip as a thank you for all the hard work.
cons: The nature of the work is basically that of a production environment. Work, work, work...pump out as many analyses as possible. Your production output is measured very closely in a spreadsheet that everyone can see. Most of the engineers are working with software that is not used in the consultant world...it is owned and used only by the company, which can hinder an individual's skill set. It is assumed the you are to spend your own time to learn what you would normally learn on the job anywhere else. So basically, you work in the production mill as the whip is is cracked and you learn pertinent information on your off time after all the overtime. For the time being, just plug away and make sure the production goal is met, and if it isn't...overtime will be required/suggested/implied....depending on how management wants to word it or employ fear tactics on the occasion. You will receive very short notice to complete certain assignments. I have witnessed it. And you will be pressured into doing whatever it takes to help the team. Many times, there are very unrealistic goals and management has a bunch of guys fresh out of college that will many times just do what they are told, without questioning anything, and more or less create a consensus and general acceptance of a workplace with low morale and long hours. Management takes this as the green light to establish this as a standard for every one to abide by. In other words, if someone else jumps off of a bridge, it will be expected for you to to do the same...very micromanaging and sad from a corporation that does nothing but speak of record highs and bright futures on every conference call and every meeting. At one point, the entire engineering department of very hard working and dedicated individuals, was required to work half of a day on employee appreciation day after it had been confirmed that we were to have the day off to enjoy a baseball game in appreciation for the sacrifices that many people make to their work-life balance for the business. The communique was sent out a few hours before end of business the previous day. What a great way to thank your employees. Too many layers. Takes forever to get decisions approved. A few individuals that have their head above the clouds and are company men to the fullest...good for them. Again, don't expect that to become the standard from everyone else. I have seen the guy that chases around management and is a yes-man, treating the guys above like gods and the people below him like peons, advance very quickly in this setting...poor judge of character on behalf of management. Strong leadership should embrace people who bring different ideas and speak up. Ladies and gentlemen, despite all of this and much of what was left out, the job is an ok starter opportunity, but after a while you will see that all that matters is production and squeezing every last dollars worth out ambitious young men and women. I hate to be the one leaving an overall bad review for a company that I have had higher hopes for from the start. Again, this is one opinion and you would have to see for yourself to agree or disagree.

On the one hand you have clients who have a laundry list of complaints about our systems. And who can blame them? The systems are an embarrassment for a company of that size. They're so bad that I would guess that they cost the average user 2 hours a day in lost productivity. But to make matters worse, you have an IT group that is in a state of denial. It takes 10 mouse clicks to select "OK" in a program? That's within normal parameters. But we have a workaround where you only have to click 8 times. Problem solved. When IT does a project, we are told to help "guide" the customer about what they want, not the other way around. Listening to the customer is not in the vocabulary. It's our way or forget about getting anything done. I left because I was tired of being the bad guy. When I took the "company" position with customers, I got yelled at by them. title: ATC IT Shared Services Center - Promise of Stability and Growth
pros: I have been working with ATC India IT Shared Services Centre, as Senior Member Technical Staff, for around 2 years. I am proud of being a part of this Fortune 500 company and I want to share my experience working with the organization, for others to read and reflect upon it. Pros: 1. You get immediate exposure to working with Global colleagues. Its a great learning experience and surely works well for your CV, If you have worked with clients or colleagues in multiple geographies. It makes you aware of their culture, helps you build your communication and makes you confident working successfully in a remote delivery model 2. If you love independence in your work, if you love space and opportunity in work you will like this place. I love it, since I have the freedom to suggest improvements and drive them on my own. I get full support. If you are used to working in an instruction led and rigid environment, you will call this place not having the best processes. 3. The technology stack is wide and employees are encouraged to cross-skill and work on multiple technology platforms. If you have a learnt new technology, you dont have to struggle or wait to get into a new project. You can try your hands on a small project or task in the new technology area while continuing with your primary deliveries. Its pretty difficult to get such ample and easy learning opportunities in other organizations and the leadership continuously encourages people to learn more, acquire new skills and stay hands on. There is no fear of being on bench, there is no blood shed over delivery, delivery process is matured, technology is up-to-date - I don't think I could ask for more. And yes, I would love to learn about one more organization where a Salesforce resource gets opportunity to learn mulesfot. A Manual Tester gets opportunity to work as a Product Business Analyst. And this happens here without any fuss. I haven't seen another place ( may be I haven't switched enough:)) where people get trained on a new technology within a month of their joining and seamlessly deployed into new projects. Yes, it needs people with self drive as well. I have seen many examples, where people have joined this organization with ZERO experience and walked out as veterans in just 2 years. There must be something the organization has to offer !! But if you are the lazy children of god, aspiring a 5-star training center in Mysore or Trivandrum to pamper you into training, this may not be the place for you. 4. Prior to joining ATC India SSC, I was working with a MNC where work from home was the norm and I was quite used to it. Here we dont have Work From Home policy. I was initially skeptical. I was like how would I survive without work from home ? Would I be able to manage my home along with work ?? Trust me, I never faced any challenge in last 18 months I have worked here. If I had a delivery to do and an urgent work at home, organization always supported me. Timings are flexible. Managers are understanding. Onsite colleagues are friendly. There are enough leaves ( and I mean it :)) in your balance. Here neither people nor policies are rigid, like most other places I have worked before. So life is easy and comfortable at ATC India SSC. 5. I had always worked for large IT organizations that used to be hierarchical. ATC India SSC has 150+ employees and structure is pretty flat. Most objective appraisal cycle. No bias. No discrimination. And I think organization is a way too generous while doling out bonus to employees. If you are an average performer, your 100% bonus is still assured. If you are a good performer you have potential to earn higher bonus. I would love to learn of another organization that is as generous if not more!! And In the end, I dont want to stress too much on the free snacks, munches that we enjoy, proximity to metro station, celebrations and festivities that we have in our lives here. We are actually going to get more in coming days !
cons: 1. ATC India SSC Doesn’t advertise like other captive centers or IT organizations. So many people are not aware of this company. One of the reasons, why I thought of sharing my experience here, while I am still working here. 2. Cafeteria : The center needs better food options in the cafeteria. struggle and search is on ! Thankfully if you walk out of the building and food options are in abundance. So this has not bothered me much. 3. We do not have 2000 people in the office. So many of us do not get the opportunity to do nothing and get comfortably lost in the crowd...each one us is being taken care of, being thought of, being talked to. So if I am the one who loves coming to office and walking out without anyone noticing my presence, If I hate attention, I am not going to like this place.
